block.p: The diagramed deal features another great piece of declarer play during the White House Teams event in Amsterdam last February.
West led the spade three. The diagramed deal features another great piece of declarer play during the White House Teams event in Amsterdam last February.
The diagramed deal features another great piece of declarer play during the White House Teams event in Amsterdam last February.

The deal was the fifth in the fifth-round match between Walid El Ahmady, Mohamed Heshmat, Tarek Nadim and Tarek Sadek of Egypt, and Krzysztof Jassem and Krzysztof Martens of Poland; and Rose Meltzer, Roger Bates, Kyle Larsen and Alan Sontag of the United States, and Geir Helgemo and Tor Helness of Norway.

Martens (South) opened one club, strong and artificial. You might have expected Helness (West) to make a two-suited overcall, but that would have been a double-edged sword. It would have increased the chance of finding a fit and being able to pre-empt the auction, but since the opponents probably would have bought the contract, West feared it would have aided declarer's play.

After West bid one diamond, the double by Jassem (North) showed four or more hearts. Helgemo (East), not liking diamonds, suggested spades as a trump suit, which steered his opponents away from a suit in which some North-South pairs played in other matches. South bid two clubs, natural and forcing. North raised his partner's suit. And South cue-bid three diamonds, which North assumed was asking him to bid three no-trump with a diamond stopper.

But when North did that, and South continued with four diamonds, North now knew that his partner had a first-round diamond control and was looking for a club slam. North's five clubs denied a major-suit control. That was good news for South, so he raised to six clubs.

Declarer took the spade lead with his ace and played the club jack, which East did well to duck. (If East had won and led back a trump, South probably would have won on the board, ruffed three hearts in his hand, using the spade queen and diamond king as the other dummy entries, ruffed a spade on the board and removed East's final club with dummy's ten. Declarer would have won three spades, two diamonds, four clubs and three heart ruffs.)

If South had played a second club at Trick 3, East would have won and returned his last trump to defeat the contract. Instead, declarer played a diamond to dummy's king and cashed the spade queen, learning that West had begun with 1-5-7-0 distribution. (With 1-6-6-0, West would not have overcalled one diamond.) Declarer ruffed a heart in his hand, took the spade king, discarding the diamond three from the board, and ruffed his diamond jack with dummy's club ten.
East did as well as possible, discarding a heart, but South ruffed two hearts in his hand and two spades on the board to give this end position:
Declarer, by leading the heart queen from the board, scored his club king with a coup en passant.
At the other table South made five clubs exactly, so the Egypt-Poland team gained 11 international match points on the way to a win in the match.
It is impressive when declarer has to be card-perfect for 12 tricks, as Martens, a world champion in 1984 and 1997, was on this deal.
